transformed_texts:
Right, so I reckon the Catholic Church needs a bit of a revamp, you know? They're losing followers, and I think it's because they're not exactly open-minded about a lot of stuff. Like, gay marriage, abortion, birth control - the Catholic Church's got some pretty strong, and frankly, kinda outdated views on these things. I get that they have beliefs, but sometimes they seem stuck in the past.  If they loosened up a bit, maybe they wouldn't be sweating about losing people. People are starting to ditch the Church because they disagree with their stance on these things. They think the Church is on the wrong side of history, you know?  Take abortion, for example. The Church is against it, and if you're pro-choice, you probably wouldn't feel comfortable being part of a group that condemns it. Same with gay marriage. If you believe in it, you might not want to be in a place that doesn't. 

I mean, why can't they have female priests? Why can't priests be married? It seems like a no-brainer to me! Maybe that could've stopped some of the drama, but who knows? It's hard to say for sure. It's like, they're saying priests are married to God, but everyone else has a job and a family life.  Why can't they have both?

Y'know,  I'm not against gay marriage, not one bit. I think, uh, whether someone's born that way or, you know, whatever, it ain't like a choice you make on purpose, ya know? So, I think, uh, folks shouldn't be blamed for bein' gay or whatever. It just seems wrong to me that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two people of the same sex can't.  

I ain't really thought about it too much, but, uh, yeah, it just seems wrong to me. Like, it ain't a choice, ya know? Like, I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It just seems like it's how you are, and you shouldn't be held responsible for that.

(clears throat)  

Yeah, I think it's wrong to say they can't get married. I don't think the government should be involved, 'cause it ain't really a legal thing, or even a moral issue, really.  I mean, these folks, they shouldn't be, uh, put on a platform like they made a bad choice or somethin'.  It ain't right.

The federal government shouldn't have a say in it. It's just, it's nothin' to do with the country's safety or morals or anythin'. They're just lettin' their noses into folks' lives, and that ain't right. It's just who they are, you know? They shouldn't be punished for it.

I mean, it's hard to explain, but, yeah, I just think they should be left alone.

Okay, so, hear me out on this gay marriage thing.  It's like, there's really no good reason not to do it, you know?  A bunch of folks think gay couples are gonna mess up the whole "straight family" thing, but honestly, it's just not the same.  It's like, two sides of the same coin, right? Different, but still connected.  Think of it like this, it's not about heads or tails, it's just different faces of the same darn thing.  

And, get this, there are all these rights tied up in marriage, like taxes and health care.  It's a real bummer when your partner can't be there for you when you're sick because they're not "family" in the eyes of the law.  I mean, if you're gonna spend your life with someone, shouldn't they be there for you? 

Plus, science, man, science!  There've been tons of studies, and guess what? Gay couples are just as happy and successful as straight couples.  It's all about love and connection, the same stuff that makes any relationship work.

Look, gay folks aren't asking to get married in a church, they just want a legal document, a marriage certificate.  It's about government recognition, not religious approval.  And if church and state are supposed to be separate, why should religion get in the way of this?  I mean, if you're okay with civil unions, why not full-blown marriage?  It's like, separate but unequal, right?  

Then there's the whole adoption thing, and how people worry about gay families affecting the community.  What about the kids?  Will they be okay?  Well, studies are still happening, but it's pretty clear that parenting skills are the same for everyone, regardless of who they love.  It's about love and care, not sexual orientation.  

I think the government should totally step in and make gay marriage legal everywhere.  We need an amendment that says yes, absolutely!  It's just common sense, really.  

But, you know, President Bush seems pretty set in his ways, probably because of his religion.  It's a bummer because it feels like a lot of this comes down to morality, and morality is different for everyone.  It's not right to force one group's beliefs on everyone else, especially when it comes to something as personal as marriage.  

And, honestly, a lot of folks who are against gay marriage think gay people are somehow broken or damaged, like it's a choice or a disease.  But the American Psychological Association has said that's not true. It's just prejudice and ignorance.  We need to listen to experts and evidence, not to our friends or what's popular.

Alright, so listen, I work at a hospital pharmacy, right?  And lemme tell ya, just 'cause something's illegal don't mean it's all bad. I mean, think about it, there are loads of drugs we use in the pharmacy that are totally illegal for the public, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet - those are all controlled substances, but we use 'em all the time 'cause they actually help people. So why deny those benefits just because there's some stink around marijuana? It's like, get real!  

I get it, alcohol's legal, and people can still abuse it, but marijuana ain't exactly harmless itself if you go overboard.  It's a tricky one, but I think we should ease into legalizing it, ya know?  Not just jump in headfirst, 'cause that'd be a disaster. We gotta ditch this whole "marijuana is evil" image first. Once people see it's not the devil's lettuce, maybe they'll use it responsibly, especially for medical stuff.  It ain't heroin or cocaine, for crying out loud!

So, the church, I think it's totally changed with the times, you know? Not as strict as it used to be. Like, when I was a kid, I'd go to church every Sunday, all dressed up. Little dresses, matching shoes, the whole shebang! I went to a private school, so all my friends were there too on the weekends. We'd just go, no big deal. 

But now that I'm older, they've got this "teenager mass" thing, thirty minutes tops, super casual.  People show up straight from the beach in their swimsuits during summer, families running in late. Even at the morning masses, where I used to dress to the nines, now it's jeans and khakis. Don't get me wrong, khakis are cool, but it's a lot less fancy now.  

That's the biggest change I've noticed, honestly. I mean, that's the church I know. I don't really know about all the political stuff going on behind the scenes, but yeah, that's it. 

Speaking of the church, those accusations against priests, the whole pedophilia thing... I don't think changing things like allowing female priests or letting them get married would have stopped it. You've got married guys out there who are pedophiles too, right? It's just about the person, not whether or not they're married.

Besides, becoming a priest is a choice. There are other religions where they get married, like on "7th Heaven" or whatever.  If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should look into a different church.

You see, I think it's kind of like genetics.  People are born with certain tendencies, you know?  It's not something that's learned. It might be influenced a little by upbringing, but mostly it's just who they are. You can't really change that with marriage, can you? 

Maybe the church could have done something if they knew about it and covered it up, but I don't think they knew about everything.

So, I'm not okay with the whole Iraq War thing, you know? Like, yeah, we were all shook after 9/11. But I think the Bush crew used that fear to push us into Iraq, waving around these claims about Saddam Hussein and WMDs - stuff that turned out to be total BS.  

It really grinds my gears that they lied to the American people, plain and simple. Even Colin Powell, he's admitted now he wasn't convinced by the evidence when he was strutting around the UN! That's messed up, man. That's like, grounds for impeachment, right?  

And honestly, the whole Bush administration seems to have this disregard for the Constitution, especially since 9/11. It's like they're trying to shove it aside. 

I get this feeling they came into office wanting to go to war, and I hear whispers about that crazy ex-treasury guy who spilled the beans in his book after getting kicked out. It seems like Bush Jr. had a bone to pick with Saddam, maybe because of what happened to his dad. Plus, he probably wanted to snatch up Iraq's oil reserves - real sneaky move, don't you think?

Look, I know pulling out now would be a mess, probably spark a civil war, and more people would die. But this whole UN and regional powers trying to fix things? I'm not so sure about that either. It's like, who are they to decide what happens in Iraq? It messes with Iraq's sovereignty, you know? 

And their government? A total shambles. Their Parliament's a joke, the Prime Minister's got no real power, and remember that guy, al-Sadr, the one we were fighting not too long ago? Well, his party controls a chunk of Parliament now! It's all just a big, fractious mess.

I mean, this whole Iraq thing is a mess, right?  It feels pointless, like a knee-jerk reaction to 9/11.  We just went in there because we thought they were responsible, but honestly, I don't know the details.  It's not like a proper war, you know?  Congress never officially declared it.  

They say we're there to build democracy and secure oil, but it's just making everyone angry.  We're trying to force democracy on a country that's not ready for it, and if we leave, they'll be even more screwed. It's a lose-lose situation.

Honestly, I'm not sure what the answer is.  It's a tough topic, and I don't have all the answers.  Maybe we should just try to help them out, but it feels like we're wasting resources and making things worse.  It's got this whole Vietnam vibe, you know?  Bush is going to be remembered for this forever, just like Vietnam.

Plus, what about the soldiers?  Their families are suffering too.  But at the same time, we're disrupting their culture, forcing our values on them.  It's just creating more hatred and division. 

It's a tangled mess.  I just wish there was a better way.

Ugh, I just don't feel right about making this legal or having the state declare it so. It seems like it should be up to the churches, ya know? The Constitution even says separation of church and state – it's pretty clear! Trying to force any kind of power over this feels like going against what's already written in stone.  

It's like, the people trying to make it illegal are basically picking one church's beliefs over another.  I mean, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except maybe up in Boston and some places like that. But it just doesn't seem right for the government to decide what churches can and can't make legal or illegal. 

Separation of church and state is a huge part of the Constitution and allows for religious tolerance in the US. Even though they talked about making an amendment, I think that's totally wrong and goes against what's already there. Plus, it would probably be one of the only amendments used to restrict the people instead of the government. That just feels off.

I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this at all. I don't get why someone would push for this amendment unless it's just because of their own personal beliefs as a Catholic. It seems like they're favoring one religion over all the others. It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone in government.  There's no real reason to back this amendment other than personal views. I don't see how it would affect the economy or anything else.  Maybe it could even help society more than hurt it.

Right, so about this Iraq war thing... I don't think the government played straight with the American people about why we went in. Before invading, they tried to tie it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really connected. They used the public's fear and anger after 9/11 to push the invasion in 2003, which I think was a big mistake.

See, I'm against war in general, especially preemptive strikes. This whole Iraq thing feels like a repeat of Vietnam – the government didn't learn from past blunders. So many American soldiers have died, and for what? They went in, toppled the government, but weren't ready for the chaos that followed. They were trying to install a democracy, just like in Vietnam, pushing out Communism and putting in their own system. But they should have known it wouldn't be easy.

It's not like a quick victory.  Even if some Iraqis wanted us there, there'd always be resistance, a bunch of angry citizens fighting back. It's a tough situation, and I think the government misled the people, making it seem like a simple mission.  

They didn't plan for the long haul. It takes time to build a stable government, like it did here in the US. It wasn't easy, with all the struggle and civil war. We're still there, years later, training Iraqi troops, and it's a slow process. The government should have been honest about the challenges involved.

And here's the thing, why just Iraq? Why not other countries that need "democratizing"?  It feels like it's all about the oil, controlling resources, and that's not a strong enough reason to risk so many lives. Plus, they said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but never found any. Meanwhile, places like North Korea have them, and we're not doing anything about it.

It all feels a bit shady to me.

I just hope it ends soon, and there's peace there eventually. But I'm not holding my breath.

Alright, so lemme tell ya, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been. I mean, it's a personal thing, right?  And you know, more and more, science is showing it's probably biological, not just some choice people make. So, like, why take away someone's rights just 'cause of something they can't control?  Seems kinda messed up to me.  I've always been a big supporter of gay marriage.

Honestly, politics and government shouldn't even be in this. It's personal, between people, not some big state or national issue.  Heck, in my old neighborhood, there were a couple gay couples, not married 'cause they couldn't be, but they lived just like any other family. Walked their dogs, you know?  It's ridiculous that Bush is trying to play God and decide what marriage means. 

And listen, I've read all sorts of stuff,  studies and news reports, saying it's actually a thing in your brain, like a chemical thing that makes you gay.  Not like you grow up with brothers and sisters and that's why you're gay. It's biological, not sociological. 

Besides the obvious, it's just weird that a guy and a girl can get married secretly in Vegas and nobody cares, but two guys or two girls want to get hitched and it's front-page news.

It should be totally private, a personal thing, not some big public spectacle.

Okay, so, hear me out.  When you post something online, it's like shouting it from the rooftops – everyone can see it.  As a Resident Advisor, I've dealt with this firsthand.  What you put out there, it shapes how people see you.  If you're talking about blowing things up or shootings, someone's gonna freak out.  You can't just toss that out there for the world to see.  The internet is a big ol' public square.  If you're friends with someone on Myspace, boom, they get that bulletin.  

Now, it's not like the school directly saw it, someone went to them, and they had to act.  They can't just ignore it, right?  What if something actually happens? They'd be in trouble for not doing anything.  But then again, sometimes people just mess around online.  It could be a sociology class experiment gone wrong, ya know?  Or it could be something serious.

In this case, someone overheard something at school, told someone, and it got passed on.  They looked through this kid's Facebook, and some stuff on there, meant as a joke, suddenly looked super scary.  When you put stuff online, there's no such thing as privacy.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  You can't control how people interpret it, or what they take seriously.

I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook, snooping through their profiles.  But if it's brought to their attention, it's not really an invasion of privacy, because it's information they got from someone who shared it.  If there's a threat, they have to take it seriously.

It's different if they're monitoring phone calls and texts, that's crossing a line. But if it's brought to their attention, that's another story.  

Just think, a teacher shouldn't create a fake profile to friend their students.  That's creepy!  I wouldn't friend my residents because frankly, I don't want to know if they're out partying and posting pics on Facebook.  It's not my place, and it's none of my business.

Man, this whole war just feels dragged out, you know? I get it, the idea at the start was cool, right? Like, bringing democracy to a place that really needed it.  But now? It feels like we've totally lost sight of that. We're just doing it for show, proving we're some kind of world superpower or something. I even think maybe the reasons for starting it in the first place were kinda shady, with all that old stuff about Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein.

I mean, if the goal was to help a country get a fair political system, that's a good reason to go to war. But if there was any personal crap mixed in there, that's not cool. Either way, it's gone on way too long. We made our point in the first few months, hitting 'em hard and showing them we weren't messing around. But years later, it's just... pointless.

It feels like we're fighting for the sake of fighting now. We don't want to back down without a clear win, a big victory. But honestly, it's time to cut our losses. Their government has to figure things out eventually, and it's been long enough. We're spending billions, draining our own economy, when we have our own problems here at home, like poverty and fixing our schools and healthcare. That money should be going to help our own people, not to keep this war going for no good reason.

I just think it's time to walk away. We've been bleeding money and lives for a cause we've lost. It's time to bring our soldiers home and focus on fixing our own mess.

So, like, someone's asking if it's okay that someone found info on Myspace and stopped something bad from happening.  

I get it, it's a sticky situation.  I mean, on Myspace, if you put stuff out there, it's kinda public, right?  Like, yeah, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile, but you're choosing to be their friend, so you're giving them permission.  It's weird to think that stuff can be used against you, you know? 

It's tough to say if it's right for someone to be watching everyone's profiles all the time.  Like, they can't possibly look at everyone, and it kinda feels like picking on people if they only focus on the "bad kids."  It'd be like, "Let's spy on those who might cause trouble." That's not cool.  

But I guess it depends on the situation.  Were they looking for something specific, or just randomly snooping? 


I have Facebook, and it freaks me out knowing creepy people can see stuff about me.  I saw this thing on TV where this guy showed how easy it is to find info about people. He found a girl's screen name and was chatting with her on instant messenger within a minute, and then got her to meet up!  That's insane, I'd never do that!

 I've had people in my classes message me on Facebook, even though they don't know me in real life. It's creepy because they know my name, my interests, even where I am during the day.  It's hard to know who to trust. I try to keep my stuff private, but then it's hard to connect with friends. 

It's a weird balance, you know?   


I heard my roommate say that her high school banned Myspace. That seems kinda over the top, though.  How can they control what we do outside of school?

Ugh, I dunno, it's just frustrating, you know?  Talking about the Iraq War feels kinda hypocritical, like I'm jumping on the bandwagon. I mean, I was against it from the start, but it's hard to say it matters now, 'cause everyone's against it except, like, the people in charge who don't wanna admit they were wrong.

It's crazy, every poll - American, Iraqi, global - shows like 75 to 80 percent of people think it was a bad idea. Even the troops over there, 70 percent of them, think we should pull out within a year!

It's a mess, total disaster from the beginning, and it's gonna be a disaster to leave too.  The whole Middle East is just so complicated. It's like trying to force democracy on people who don't want it, you know? It's a cultural clash, and our government just doesn't get it.

Yeah, Saddam was bad, but invading was such a huge gamble, and it's just turned into quicksand. I don't even know what to say about it anymore.

I just don't see any reason to stay. I'm sure they have some reasons, but haven't heard anything convincing yet. If they wanna pull out gradually, over a year or so, I guess that's okay, but just leaving now seems the best option. 

Eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone within a year, a quarter of them want us gone now!  We're trying to help them, but they're telling us to leave.  Maybe they know better than we do.

At least if we ask them what they want, and they say leave, then it's not on us if things go south. We could be like, "Hey, you guys said you wanted us out."

We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but at least we'd be trying to do the right thing.

So, yeah, I think gender discrimination is still a real thing in the U.S., and it's not just women who feel it. It kind of depends on the field you're in, you know? 

For women, there's still that "glass ceiling." Even though we're supposed to be equal, a lot of guys have a hard time working under a woman boss. It's just how society's been for ages. 

So, women might be super qualified for a job, but the board might not choose them because, historically, women aren't seen as top leaders. And it's the same deal for guys in some fields, like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. 

It's super uncommon to see a dad at home, and people judge them for it. Society expects men to be the breadwinners, so they think, "Why isn't he out working?"  It sucks because maybe he's always dreamed of being with his kids and helping out, even if his wife has the better job. 

And in fashion, straight dudes sometimes get overlooked because people think, "How can a guy really know about fashion?"  They assume dudes in fashion must be living a different sort of life, so they question their expertise. 

It's all about these outdated stereotypes, and it's tough to change because society's got its groove.  

We've come a long way from the 1800s, but change is slow. More women are becoming CEOs, and stay-at-home dads are more accepted, but it's a gradual process.  

It's like, we can't force it, or people will resist. We gotta show people the good stuff about these stereotyped roles – the amazing qualities of women in leadership, dads at home, and dudes in fashion – and let them see the value.

So, they didn't exactly legalize it, ya know? They went for decriminalization.  Think of it like this: it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic ticket. You get cited, not nabbed, booked, and thrown in a cell.  But here's the thing, even with decriminalization, those job interview worries and other hassles still linger. Future consequences, they stick around.  It's a conundrum, really. Arresting, booking, housing folks, court appearances, public defenders, judges, prosecutors - it all costs a bundle.  And for municipalities struggling financially, that's a big pill to swallow, even if it frees up cash for schools, social programs, and helping the less fortunate.   

It's a matter of philosophy, too. Some places are staunchly against marijuana, no ifs, ands, or buts. But in places like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, well, it seems like a win-win. They probably have more dough to spend on important stuff now.

But here's the thing, I'm not saying we should just go wild with marijuana, like cigarettes in every gas station. It's still a sensitive subject, and having it out in the open might feel weird to some.

What about driving under the influence? Alcohol's a bigger threat to driving, but weed can mess with your life in other ways, ya know? It's a personal thing, really. Some people handle it better than others.

Bottom line: both have downsides, and how folks react varies. It's a tricky issue, no easy answers.

You know, I'd say "yeah," to Catholicism, 'cause a lot of what they do is rooted in tradition, and that's a good thing. It's important to have those roots, you know? But at the same time, you gotta be able to bend with the times, gotta be adaptable. 

I guess a lot of Catholics think they have to be in church every week, and they're pretty strict about how things are done.  Sometimes it feels like they look down on folks who don't follow the rules perfectly, like they don't accept people who aren't cookie-cutter Catholics. And they're not exactly open to other religions, either.

For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't marry them in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. That doesn't seem too loving to me. They preach about loving everyone, but then they turn around and don't accept people who aren't exactly like them. It feels hypocritical, you know?

It's like they tell you to do one thing, but then their actions say something else. Their practices feel outdated, stuck in the past, but they keep clinging to them anyway. 

I think it would be cool if priests could get married, but I don't think that would stop them from doing bad things. It's a different issue altogether.

Honestly, people who hurt kids are gonna hurt kids, no matter if they're married or not. It's not about having a spouse; it's about something else entirely.

Man, this whole marriage thing is a real head-scratcher.  I haven't quite figured it out yet. It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage actually means. It's tough, you know?  

I mean, think about it.  If we're talking about marriage as a sacred thing, like a religious sacrament, shouldn't the government stay out of it? Just like they don't mess with folks who get baptized, right?  Maybe it's simpler to just see marriage as a civil union, a legal recognition of two people who want to be together.

It's all about two people joining forces, no matter who they are.  The government shouldn't care if it's a church wedding or a courthouse ceremony. They should just recognize it as a union, plain and simple.

Now, with gay marriage, it's like, hey, if two people want to commit to each other, why not let them?  It seems pretty straightforward to me.  If all the states can agree on something, maybe it's time to make it federal law.

But, banning gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just crazy talk! The constitution shouldn't be changed for something like this. Sure, it's important to some people, but it's not something that deserves to be written into the law of the land. It's just not that big a deal.

So, growing up in a Christian household, homosexuality is a bit of a complicated thing for me. I've got plenty of gay friends, you know? I guess I don't totally agree with their lifestyle, but I think it's something everyone should have the right to choose.  It shouldn't be a national battle, though.  Each state should decide for themselves.  

It's kinda like how some states lean Democrat and others lean Republican.  Democratic states are more likely to push for gay marriage, and if you're living in one of those states, you're kinda accepting that's how things are there.  You chose to live there, right?

Look, I think everyone, gay or straight, should have the same opportunities.  So yeah, I'm all for legalizing it, but I think it should be up to each state to decide.  

It's not right for someone like Bush to tell the whole country what they can and can't do.  Gay marriage should be decided at a state level, not by the president. He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to make that call for everyone.  It's just not his place.  Besides, he's leaving office soon anyway. If a Democrat comes in and wants to overturn the ban, it's just gonna keep going back and forth. Let each state decide what's best for them. They're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Okay, so, Myspace is like, totally public, right? It's like a bulletin board for everyone to see. If you post something there, you gotta know people, like, even the school, could see it.  I mean, even if they weren't using the school's name, they could still check it out from home. 

But here's the thing:  if checking Myspace helps keep students safe, like, prevents a shooting, then I think it's totally okay. It's the school's job to keep everyone safe, you know? 

I get that some people think it's an invasion of privacy if the school is just snooping around for stuff like drinking or smoking. But, if they're trying to stop something bad from happening, like a shooting, I don't see it as an invasion.

It's kinda like how I don't just say anything bad about people in emails. I mean, you never know who might see it later, right? Everything you post online kinda stays there forever. Like, what if you do something dumb as a college student and then, years later, some big-shot finds that email? Oops.

So, yeah, I think if the school is using Myspace to keep kids safe, that's totally legit.

Ok, so, about this whole war thing... at first, I was totally on board. Nine eleven hit close to home, you know? I wanted revenge, to make them pay for what they did. I think it was all fueled by emotion, though. We went in there unprepared, without a real plan. It was like a knee-jerk reaction. 

Now, looking back, I'm totally against it. I don't think it achieved anything. It's like, if those people can't even get along with each other, what makes us think we can fix things?  Honestly, because of nine eleven, I've just become numb to what's happening over there. Those people... I don't even know if they're human. They're so locked in their own conflicts, they can't see beyond themselves.

We went in blind, clueless about what we'd face. War is different there, brutal and savage. They're not fighting for a better future, they just want us out.  I think we should just leave. 

We were hyped up on anger and revenge, not thinking about the consequences. President Bush probably felt pressured too, the people wanted action. But, declaring war on Iraq, that was a huge decision.  I get where he was coming from, but we should have had a better plan. What were we even trying to achieve? There was no clear goal, no unity of purpose. 

It's like we went in there expecting to change their whole way of life, but we're not the ones to do that. They're too entrenched in their own ways.  


We've made some progress, but it's not enough to justify staying there forever. We're just prolonging the pain, hurting ourselves in the process. It's time to move on.

transformed_texts:
Right, so I reckon the Catholic Church needs a bit of a revamp, you know? They're losing followers, and I think it's because they're not exactly open-minded about a lot of stuff. Like, gay marriage, abortion, birth control - the Catholic Church's got some pretty strong, and frankly, kinda outdated views on these things. I get that they have beliefs, but sometimes they seem stuck in the past.  If they loosened up a bit, maybe they wouldn't be sweating about losing people. People are starting to ditch the Church because they disagree with their stance on these things. They think the Church is on the wrong side of history, you know?  Take abortion, for example. The Church is against it, and if you're pro-choice, you probably wouldn't feel comfortable being part of a group that condemns it. Same with gay marriage. If you believe in it, you might not want to be in a place that doesn't. 

I mean, why can't they have female priests? Why can't priests be married? It seems like a no-brainer to me! Maybe that could've stopped some of the drama, but who knows? It's hard to say for sure. It's like, they're saying priests are married to God, but everyone else has a job and a family life.  Why can't they have both?

Y'know,  I'm not against gay marriage, not one bit. I think, uh, whether someone's born that way or, you know, whatever, it ain't like a choice you make on purpose, ya know? So, I think, uh, folks shouldn't be blamed for bein' gay or whatever. It just seems wrong to me that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two people of the same sex can't.  

I ain't really thought about it too much, but, uh, yeah, it just seems wrong to me. Like, it ain't a choice, ya know? Like, I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It just seems like it's how you are, and you shouldn't be held responsible for that.

(clears throat)  

Yeah, I think it's wrong to say they can't get married. I don't think the government should be involved, 'cause it ain't really a legal thing, or even a moral issue, really.  I mean, these folks, they shouldn't be, uh, put on a platform like they made a bad choice or somethin'.  It ain't right.

The federal government shouldn't have a say in it. It's just, it's nothin' to do with the country's safety or morals or anythin'. They're just lettin' their noses into folks' lives, and that ain't right. It's just who they are, you know? They shouldn't be punished for it.

I mean, it's hard to explain, but, yeah, I just think they should be left alone.

Okay, so, hear me out on this gay marriage thing.  It's like, there's really no good reason not to do it, you know?  A bunch of folks think gay couples are gonna mess up the whole "straight family" thing, but honestly, it's just not the same.  It's like, two sides of the same coin, right? Different, but still connected.  Think of it like this, it's not about heads or tails, it's just different faces of the same darn thing.  

And, get this, there are all these rights tied up in marriage, like taxes and health care.  It's a real bummer when your partner can't be there for you when you're sick because they're not "family" in the eyes of the law.  I mean, if you're gonna spend your life with someone, shouldn't they be there for you? 

Plus, science, man, science!  There've been tons of studies, and guess what? Gay couples are just as happy and successful as straight couples.  It's all about love and connection, the same stuff that makes any relationship work.

Look, gay folks aren't asking to get married in a church, they just want a legal document, a marriage certificate.  It's about government recognition, not religious approval.  And if church and state are supposed to be separate, why should religion get in the way of this?  I mean, if you're okay with civil unions, why not full-blown marriage?  It's like, separate but unequal, right?  

Then there's the whole adoption thing, and how people worry about gay families affecting the community.  What about the kids?  Will they be okay?  Well, studies are still happening, but it's pretty clear that parenting skills are the same for everyone, regardless of who they love.  It's about love and care, not sexual orientation.  

I think the government should totally step in and make gay marriage legal everywhere.  We need an amendment that says yes, absolutely!  It's just common sense, really.  

But, you know, President Bush seems pretty set in his ways, probably because of his religion.  It's a bummer because it feels like a lot of this comes down to morality, and morality is different for everyone.  It's not right to force one group's beliefs on everyone else, especially when it comes to something as personal as marriage.  

And, honestly, a lot of folks who are against gay marriage think gay people are somehow broken or damaged, like it's a choice or a disease.  But the American Psychological Association has said that's not true. It's just prejudice and ignorance.  We need to listen to experts and evidence, not to our friends or what's popular.

Alright, so listen, I work at a hospital pharmacy, right?  And lemme tell ya, just 'cause something's illegal don't mean it's all bad. I mean, think about it, there are loads of drugs we use in the pharmacy that are totally illegal for the public, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet - those are all controlled substances, but we use 'em all the time 'cause they actually help people. So why deny those benefits just because there's some stink around marijuana? It's like, get real!  

I get it, alcohol's legal, and people can still abuse it, but marijuana ain't exactly harmless itself if you go overboard.  It's a tricky one, but I think we should ease into legalizing it, ya know?  Not just jump in headfirst, 'cause that'd be a disaster. We gotta ditch this whole "marijuana is evil" image first. Once people see it's not the devil's lettuce, maybe they'll use it responsibly, especially for medical stuff.  It ain't heroin or cocaine, for crying out loud!

So, the church, I think it's totally changed with the times, you know? Not as strict as it used to be. Like, when I was a kid, I'd go to church every Sunday, all dressed up. Little dresses, matching shoes, the whole shebang! I went to a private school, so all my friends were there too on the weekends. We'd just go, no big deal. 

But now that I'm older, they've got this "teenager mass" thing, thirty minutes tops, super casual.  People show up straight from the beach in their swimsuits during summer, families running in late. Even at the morning masses, where I used to dress to the nines, now it's jeans and khakis. Don't get me wrong, khakis are cool, but it's a lot less fancy now.  

That's the biggest change I've noticed, honestly. I mean, that's the church I know. I don't really know about all the political stuff going on behind the scenes, but yeah, that's it. 

Speaking of the church, those accusations against priests, the whole pedophilia thing... I don't think changing things like allowing female priests or letting them get married would have stopped it. You've got married guys out there who are pedophiles too, right? It's just about the person, not whether or not they're married.

Besides, becoming a priest is a choice. There are other religions where they get married, like on "7th Heaven" or whatever.  If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should look into a different church.

You see, I think it's kind of like genetics.  People are born with certain tendencies, you know?  It's not something that's learned. It might be influenced a little by upbringing, but mostly it's just who they are. You can't really change that with marriage, can you? 

Maybe the church could have done something if they knew about it and covered it up, but I don't think they knew about everything.

So, I'm not okay with the whole Iraq War thing, you know? Like, yeah, we were all shook after 9/11. But I think the Bush crew used that fear to push us into Iraq, waving around these claims about Saddam Hussein and WMDs - stuff that turned out to be total BS.  

It really grinds my gears that they lied to the American people, plain and simple. Even Colin Powell, he's admitted now he wasn't convinced by the evidence when he was strutting around the UN! That's messed up, man. That's like, grounds for impeachment, right?  

And honestly, the whole Bush administration seems to have this disregard for the Constitution, especially since 9/11. It's like they're trying to shove it aside. 

I get this feeling they came into office wanting to go to war, and I hear whispers about that crazy ex-treasury guy who spilled the beans in his book after getting kicked out. It seems like Bush Jr. had a bone to pick with Saddam, maybe because of what happened to his dad. Plus, he probably wanted to snatch up Iraq's oil reserves - real sneaky move, don't you think?

Look, I know pulling out now would be a mess, probably spark a civil war, and more people would die. But this whole UN and regional powers trying to fix things? I'm not so sure about that either. It's like, who are they to decide what happens in Iraq? It messes with Iraq's sovereignty, you know? 

And their government? A total shambles. Their Parliament's a joke, the Prime Minister's got no real power, and remember that guy, al-Sadr, the one we were fighting not too long ago? Well, his party controls a chunk of Parliament now! It's all just a big, fractious mess.

I mean, this whole Iraq thing is a mess, right?  It feels pointless, like a knee-jerk reaction to 9/11.  We just went in there because we thought they were responsible, but honestly, I don't know the details.  It's not like a proper war, you know?  Congress never officially declared it.  

They say we're there to build democracy and secure oil, but it's just making everyone angry.  We're trying to force democracy on a country that's not ready for it, and if we leave, they'll be even more screwed. It's a lose-lose situation.

Honestly, I'm not sure what the answer is.  It's a tough topic, and I don't have all the answers.  Maybe we should just try to help them out, but it feels like we're wasting resources and making things worse.  It's got this whole Vietnam vibe, you know?  Bush is going to be remembered for this forever, just like Vietnam.

Plus, what about the soldiers?  Their families are suffering too.  But at the same time, we're disrupting their culture, forcing our values on them.  It's just creating more hatred and division. 

It's a tangled mess.  I just wish there was a better way.

Ugh, I just don't feel right about making this legal or having the state declare it so. It seems like it should be up to the churches, ya know? The Constitution even says separation of church and state – it's pretty clear! Trying to force any kind of power over this feels like going against what's already written in stone.  

It's like, the people trying to make it illegal are basically picking one church's beliefs over another.  I mean, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except maybe up in Boston and some places like that. But it just doesn't seem right for the government to decide what churches can and can't make legal or illegal. 

Separation of church and state is a huge part of the Constitution and allows for religious tolerance in the US. Even though they talked about making an amendment, I think that's totally wrong and goes against what's already there. Plus, it would probably be one of the only amendments used to restrict the people instead of the government. That just feels off.

I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this at all. I don't get why someone would push for this amendment unless it's just because of their own personal beliefs as a Catholic. It seems like they're favoring one religion over all the others. It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone in government.  There's no real reason to back this amendment other than personal views. I don't see how it would affect the economy or anything else.  Maybe it could even help society more than hurt it.

Right, so about this Iraq war thing... I don't think the government played straight with the American people about why we went in. Before invading, they tried to tie it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really connected. They used the public's fear and anger after 9/11 to push the invasion in 2003, which I think was a big mistake.

See, I'm against war in general, especially preemptive strikes. This whole Iraq thing feels like a repeat of Vietnam – the government didn't learn from past blunders. So many American soldiers have died, and for what? They went in, toppled the government, but weren't ready for the chaos that followed. They were trying to install a democracy, just like in Vietnam, pushing out Communism and putting in their own system. But they should have known it wouldn't be easy.

It's not like a quick victory.  Even if some Iraqis wanted us there, there'd always be resistance, a bunch of angry citizens fighting back. It's a tough situation, and I think the government misled the people, making it seem like a simple mission.  

They didn't plan for the long haul. It takes time to build a stable government, like it did here in the US. It wasn't easy, with all the struggle and civil war. We're still there, years later, training Iraqi troops, and it's a slow process. The government should have been honest about the challenges involved.

And here's the thing, why just Iraq? Why not other countries that need "democratizing"?  It feels like it's all about the oil, controlling resources, and that's not a strong enough reason to risk so many lives. Plus, they said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but never found any. Meanwhile, places like North Korea have them, and we're not doing anything about it.

It all feels a bit shady to me.

I just hope it ends soon, and there's peace there eventually. But I'm not holding my breath.

Alright, so lemme tell ya, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been. I mean, it's a personal thing, right?  And you know, more and more, science is showing it's probably biological, not just some choice people make. So, like, why take away someone's rights just 'cause of something they can't control?  Seems kinda messed up to me.  I've always been a big supporter of gay marriage.

Honestly, politics and government shouldn't even be in this. It's personal, between people, not some big state or national issue.  Heck, in my old neighborhood, there were a couple gay couples, not married 'cause they couldn't be, but they lived just like any other family. Walked their dogs, you know?  It's ridiculous that Bush is trying to play God and decide what marriage means. 

And listen, I've read all sorts of stuff,  studies and news reports, saying it's actually a thing in your brain, like a chemical thing that makes you gay.  Not like you grow up with brothers and sisters and that's why you're gay. It's biological, not sociological. 

Besides the obvious, it's just weird that a guy and a girl can get married secretly in Vegas and nobody cares, but two guys or two girls want to get hitched and it's front-page news.

It should be totally private, a personal thing, not some big public spectacle.

Okay, so, hear me out.  When you post something online, it's like shouting it from the rooftops – everyone can see it.  As a Resident Advisor, I've dealt with this firsthand.  What you put out there, it shapes how people see you.  If you're talking about blowing things up or shootings, someone's gonna freak out.  You can't just toss that out there for the world to see.  The internet is a big ol' public square.  If you're friends with someone on Myspace, boom, they get that bulletin.  

Now, it's not like the school directly saw it, someone went to them, and they had to act.  They can't just ignore it, right?  What if something actually happens? They'd be in trouble for not doing anything.  But then again, sometimes people just mess around online.  It could be a sociology class experiment gone wrong, ya know?  Or it could be something serious.

In this case, someone overheard something at school, told someone, and it got passed on.  They looked through this kid's Facebook, and some stuff on there, meant as a joke, suddenly looked super scary.  When you put stuff online, there's no such thing as privacy.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  You can't control how people interpret it, or what they take seriously.

I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook, snooping through their profiles.  But if it's brought to their attention, it's not really an invasion of privacy, because it's information they got from someone who shared it.  If there's a threat, they have to take it seriously.

It's different if they're monitoring phone calls and texts, that's crossing a line. But if it's brought to their attention, that's another story.  

Just think, a teacher shouldn't create a fake profile to friend their students.  That's creepy!  I wouldn't friend my residents because frankly, I don't want to know if they're out partying and posting pics on Facebook.  It's not my place, and it's none of my business.

Man, this whole war just feels dragged out, you know? I get it, the idea at the start was cool, right? Like, bringing democracy to a place that really needed it.  But now? It feels like we've totally lost sight of that. We're just doing it for show, proving we're some kind of world superpower or something. I even think maybe the reasons for starting it in the first place were kinda shady, with all that old stuff about Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein.

I mean, if the goal was to help a country get a fair political system, that's a good reason to go to war. But if there was any personal crap mixed in there, that's not cool. Either way, it's gone on way too long. We made our point in the first few months, hitting 'em hard and showing them we weren't messing around. But years later, it's just... pointless.

It feels like we're fighting for the sake of fighting now. We don't want to back down without a clear win, a big victory. But honestly, it's time to cut our losses. Their government has to figure things out eventually, and it's been long enough. We're spending billions, draining our own economy, when we have our own problems here at home, like poverty and fixing our schools and healthcare. That money should be going to help our own people, not to keep this war going for no good reason.

I just think it's time to walk away. We've been bleeding money and lives for a cause we've lost. It's time to bring our soldiers home and focus on fixing our own mess.

So, like, someone's asking if it's okay that someone found info on Myspace and stopped something bad from happening.  

I get it, it's a sticky situation.  I mean, on Myspace, if you put stuff out there, it's kinda public, right?  Like, yeah, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile, but you're choosing to be their friend, so you're giving them permission.  It's weird to think that stuff can be used against you, you know? 

It's tough to say if it's right for someone to be watching everyone's profiles all the time.  Like, they can't possibly look at everyone, and it kinda feels like picking on people if they only focus on the "bad kids."  It'd be like, "Let's spy on those who might cause trouble." That's not cool.  

But I guess it depends on the situation.  Were they looking for something specific, or just randomly snooping? 


I have Facebook, and it freaks me out knowing creepy people can see stuff about me.  I saw this thing on TV where this guy showed how easy it is to find info about people. He found a girl's screen name and was chatting with her on instant messenger within a minute, and then got her to meet up!  That's insane, I'd never do that!

 I've had people in my classes message me on Facebook, even though they don't know me in real life. It's creepy because they know my name, my interests, even where I am during the day.  It's hard to know who to trust. I try to keep my stuff private, but then it's hard to connect with friends. 

It's a weird balance, you know?   


I heard my roommate say that her high school banned Myspace. That seems kinda over the top, though.  How can they control what we do outside of school?

Ugh, I dunno, it's just frustrating, you know?  Talking about the Iraq War feels kinda hypocritical, like I'm jumping on the bandwagon. I mean, I was against it from the start, but it's hard to say it matters now, 'cause everyone's against it except, like, the people in charge who don't wanna admit they were wrong.

It's crazy, every poll - American, Iraqi, global - shows like 75 to 80 percent of people think it was a bad idea. Even the troops over there, 70 percent of them, think we should pull out within a year!

It's a mess, total disaster from the beginning, and it's gonna be a disaster to leave too.  The whole Middle East is just so complicated. It's like trying to force democracy on people who don't want it, you know? It's a cultural clash, and our government just doesn't get it.

Yeah, Saddam was bad, but invading was such a huge gamble, and it's just turned into quicksand. I don't even know what to say about it anymore.

I just don't see any reason to stay. I'm sure they have some reasons, but haven't heard anything convincing yet. If they wanna pull out gradually, over a year or so, I guess that's okay, but just leaving now seems the best option. 

Eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone within a year, a quarter of them want us gone now!  We're trying to help them, but they're telling us to leave.  Maybe they know better than we do.

At least if we ask them what they want, and they say leave, then it's not on us if things go south. We could be like, "Hey, you guys said you wanted us out."

We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but at least we'd be trying to do the right thing.

So, yeah, I think gender discrimination is still a real thing in the U.S., and it's not just women who feel it. It kind of depends on the field you're in, you know? 

For women, there's still that "glass ceiling." Even though we're supposed to be equal, a lot of guys have a hard time working under a woman boss. It's just how society's been for ages. 

So, women might be super qualified for a job, but the board might not choose them because, historically, women aren't seen as top leaders. And it's the same deal for guys in some fields, like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. 

It's super uncommon to see a dad at home, and people judge them for it. Society expects men to be the breadwinners, so they think, "Why isn't he out working?"  It sucks because maybe he's always dreamed of being with his kids and helping out, even if his wife has the better job. 

And in fashion, straight dudes sometimes get overlooked because people think, "How can a guy really know about fashion?"  They assume dudes in fashion must be living a different sort of life, so they question their expertise. 

It's all about these outdated stereotypes, and it's tough to change because society's got its groove.  

We've come a long way from the 1800s, but change is slow. More women are becoming CEOs, and stay-at-home dads are more accepted, but it's a gradual process.  

It's like, we can't force it, or people will resist. We gotta show people the good stuff about these stereotyped roles – the amazing qualities of women in leadership, dads at home, and dudes in fashion – and let them see the value.

So, they didn't exactly legalize it, ya know? They went for decriminalization.  Think of it like this: it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic ticket. You get cited, not nabbed, booked, and thrown in a cell.  But here's the thing, even with decriminalization, those job interview worries and other hassles still linger. Future consequences, they stick around.  It's a conundrum, really. Arresting, booking, housing folks, court appearances, public defenders, judges, prosecutors - it all costs a bundle.  And for municipalities struggling financially, that's a big pill to swallow, even if it frees up cash for schools, social programs, and helping the less fortunate.   

It's a matter of philosophy, too. Some places are staunchly against marijuana, no ifs, ands, or buts. But in places like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, well, it seems like a win-win. They probably have more dough to spend on important stuff now.

But here's the thing, I'm not saying we should just go wild with marijuana, like cigarettes in every gas station. It's still a sensitive subject, and having it out in the open might feel weird to some.

What about driving under the influence? Alcohol's a bigger threat to driving, but weed can mess with your life in other ways, ya know? It's a personal thing, really. Some people handle it better than others.

Bottom line: both have downsides, and how folks react varies. It's a tricky issue, no easy answers.

You know, I'd say "yeah," to Catholicism, 'cause a lot of what they do is rooted in tradition, and that's a good thing. It's important to have those roots, you know? But at the same time, you gotta be able to bend with the times, gotta be adaptable. 

I guess a lot of Catholics think they have to be in church every week, and they're pretty strict about how things are done.  Sometimes it feels like they look down on folks who don't follow the rules perfectly, like they don't accept people who aren't cookie-cutter Catholics. And they're not exactly open to other religions, either.

For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't marry them in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. That doesn't seem too loving to me. They preach about loving everyone, but then they turn around and don't accept people who aren't exactly like them. It feels hypocritical, you know?

It's like they tell you to do one thing, but then their actions say something else. Their practices feel outdated, stuck in the past, but they keep clinging to them anyway. 

I think it would be cool if priests could get married, but I don't think that would stop them from doing bad things. It's a different issue altogether.

Honestly, people who hurt kids are gonna hurt kids, no matter if they're married or not. It's not about having a spouse; it's about something else entirely.

Man, this whole marriage thing is a real head-scratcher.  I haven't quite figured it out yet. It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage actually means. It's tough, you know?  

I mean, think about it.  If we're talking about marriage as a sacred thing, like a religious sacrament, shouldn't the government stay out of it? Just like they don't mess with folks who get baptized, right?  Maybe it's simpler to just see marriage as a civil union, a legal recognition of two people who want to be together.

It's all about two people joining forces, no matter who they are.  The government shouldn't care if it's a church wedding or a courthouse ceremony. They should just recognize it as a union, plain and simple.

Now, with gay marriage, it's like, hey, if two people want to commit to each other, why not let them?  It seems pretty straightforward to me.  If all the states can agree on something, maybe it's time to make it federal law.

But, banning gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just crazy talk! The constitution shouldn't be changed for something like this. Sure, it's important to some people, but it's not something that deserves to be written into the law of the land. It's just not that big a deal.

So, growing up in a Christian household, homosexuality is a bit of a complicated thing for me. I've got plenty of gay friends, you know? I guess I don't totally agree with their lifestyle, but I think it's something everyone should have the right to choose.  It shouldn't be a national battle, though.  Each state should decide for themselves.  

It's kinda like how some states lean Democrat and others lean Republican.  Democratic states are more likely to push for gay marriage, and if you're living in one of those states, you're kinda accepting that's how things are there.  You chose to live there, right?

Look, I think everyone, gay or straight, should have the same opportunities.  So yeah, I'm all for legalizing it, but I think it should be up to each state to decide.  

It's not right for someone like Bush to tell the whole country what they can and can't do.  Gay marriage should be decided at a state level, not by the president. He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to make that call for everyone.  It's just not his place.  Besides, he's leaving office soon anyway. If a Democrat comes in and wants to overturn the ban, it's just gonna keep going back and forth. Let each state decide what's best for them. They're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Okay, so, Myspace is like, totally public, right? It's like a bulletin board for everyone to see. If you post something there, you gotta know people, like, even the school, could see it.  I mean, even if they weren't using the school's name, they could still check it out from home. 

But here's the thing:  if checking Myspace helps keep students safe, like, prevents a shooting, then I think it's totally okay. It's the school's job to keep everyone safe, you know? 

I get that some people think it's an invasion of privacy if the school is just snooping around for stuff like drinking or smoking. But, if they're trying to stop something bad from happening, like a shooting, I don't see it as an invasion.

It's kinda like how I don't just say anything bad about people in emails. I mean, you never know who might see it later, right? Everything you post online kinda stays there forever. Like, what if you do something dumb as a college student and then, years later, some big-shot finds that email? Oops.

So, yeah, I think if the school is using Myspace to keep kids safe, that's totally legit.

Ok, so, about this whole war thing... at first, I was totally on board. Nine eleven hit close to home, you know? I wanted revenge, to make them pay for what they did. I think it was all fueled by emotion, though. We went in there unprepared, without a real plan. It was like a knee-jerk reaction. 

Now, looking back, I'm totally against it. I don't think it achieved anything. It's like, if those people can't even get along with each other, what makes us think we can fix things?  Honestly, because of nine eleven, I've just become numb to what's happening over there. Those people... I don't even know if they're human. They're so locked in their own conflicts, they can't see beyond themselves.

We went in blind, clueless about what we'd face. War is different there, brutal and savage. They're not fighting for a better future, they just want us out.  I think we should just leave. 

We were hyped up on anger and revenge, not thinking about the consequences. President Bush probably felt pressured too, the people wanted action. But, declaring war on Iraq, that was a huge decision.  I get where he was coming from, but we should have had a better plan. What were we even trying to achieve? There was no clear goal, no unity of purpose. 

It's like we went in there expecting to change their whole way of life, but we're not the ones to do that. They're too entrenched in their own ways.  


We've made some progress, but it's not enough to justify staying there forever. We're just prolonging the pain, hurting ourselves in the process. It's time to move on.
